awd_titl_txt: BIGDATA: IA: Enabling Large-Scale, Privacy-Preserving Genomic Computing with a Hardware-Assisted Secure Big-Data Analytics Framework
awd_abstract_narration:
Advances in DNA sequencing technologies are expected to make available a massive amount of human genomic data in the years to come, which need computation of a tremendous scale to process. This demand cannot be met by today's commercial clouds,  since they do not provide strong privacy guarantees,  or by using existing cryptography techniques, since they still cannot achieve the performance required for big-data analytics. The emergence of the new-generation hardware support for trusted execution environments presents a new opportunity for scalable data protection, through the processors designed to withstand the attacks even from a fully compromised operating system.  To seize this opportunity, this project aims at developing a distributed, parallel computing framework critical for executing data-intensive tasks on trusted execution environment-capable systems.  This research will be performed in collaboration with Intel, which will transfer the new methods developed for large-scale data protection to industry and genomic researchers.  Students from historically black colleges and universities will participate in the work.

The project focuses on developing a big-data analytics framework built on Intel Software Guard Extensions (SGX) and applying it to support privacy-preserving, large-scale genomic data analyses and other computing tasks. Based upon the understanding of unique performance impacts of SGX systems, including those incurred by enclave creation, management, trust establishment, cross-enclave communication and others, a new MPI-based cluster computing framework is built to automatically optimize the deployment of computing nodes across enclaves and CPU packages under resource constraints. This new framework supports a set of fundamental genomic computing tasks, ranging from reads-mapping to peptide identification, as well as machine-learning based models.  Also, its potential risks, side-channel leaks in particular, are analyzed and effectively controlled to provide high privacy assurance. The work will enable broad sharing of previously inaccessible data and help drive the new insights of individualized health care.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project is focused on developing advanced big-data analytics techniques using Trusted Execution Environments (TEEs) such as Intel's Software Guard Extensions (SGX). These techniques aim to ensure the privacy of large-scale biomedical computing tasks and other sensitive tasks like machine learning in commercial cloud settings. To serve this purpose, we have introduced several technical innovations that enhance scalable data-in-use protection. These include establishing trust with programs running in SGX enclaves and other TEEs, identifying and mitigating side-channel leaks at runtime, among others. These advancements bring us closer to enabling the effective and privacy-preserving sharing of sensitive data, particularly in the healthcare sector, thus facilitating technological progress in essential areas.

 

Intellectual Merits: Throughout the project, we developed a series of SGX-based big-data analysis techniques to secure crucial bioinformatics computing tasks. This includes collaborative training of Generalized Linear Mixed Models (GLMM) for genomic data analysis and genotype imputation for determining missing genotypes. We generalized these techniques to create an MPI prototype on the SGX platform, which allowed us to analyze and enhance the performance of cutting-edge biomedical data analytics tasks within the TEE. This understanding led to the development of a hybrid secured flow framework (HySec-Flow) for large-scale genomic data analysis. The framework divides a genomic computing task into independent subtasks involving sensitive and non-sensitive data, which are handled in different containers with varying levels of protection.  It was further optimized to support parallel execution based upon the unique features of SGX.  To effectively deploy the framework for a cloud-based genomic data analysis service, it is essential to enable the genomic data owner to confirm that the code inside the SGX enclave manages her data in accordance with her data use policies. Crucially, this verification must occur without revealing the proprietary bioinformatics algorithms to the data owner. To address this challenge, we developed DEFLECTION, a middleware designed for SGX-based delegated and flexible in-enclave code verification.

 

With the evolution of TEE hardware, including Intel’s TDX, AMD’s SEV, and ARM’s CCA, our focus has expanded beyond SGX to develop confidential computing support for big-data analytics that are less dependent on any specific TEE hardware technique. Notably, we enhanced DEFLECTION to support a public service operating within a TEE that verifies and certifies a biomedical program’s adherence to data use policies. We also introduced a critical feature for secure big data analytics, the Proof of Being Forgotten, which ensures the removal of private biomedical data post-service completion. Additionally, we explored potential threats to TEE-based confidential genomic computing, particularly those exploiting DRAM vulnerabilities, and investigated potential mitigations. These developments enhance our capability for scalable and effective data-in-use protection, contributing to the technological advances that will lead to broader use of affordable cloud resources for analyzing private healthcare data, thereby reducing the healthcare costs without compromising patient privacy.

 

Broader Impacts: The results of this project have been extensively shared at prominent security, biomedical, and cloud computing conferences. The PIs led the organization of the iDASH Genome Privacy Competition, which included TEE-based genome computing tracks attended by tens of international teams every year, and the IEEE Cloud Computing Conference (CLOUD’23) featuring a TEE-related track. Furthermore, the project provided valuable research training on confidential computing to an HBCU student through a summer internship. These efforts not only advance our understanding of confidential computing but also foster global collaboration and educational opportunities in the field.
